Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Spin dependent transport properties of semiconducting nanostructures

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Proposal Title: Spin dependent transport properties of semiconducting nanostructures

John Philip, The Catholic University of America

The objective of this research is to explore methods to improve the efficiency of carrier spin transport through ferromagnet/semiconductor device structures. The approach is to reduce the depletion region in a ferromagnet/semiconductor interface and tune the interface resistance-area product for achieving large spin transport for realizing practical devices. This approach is explored on technologically important semiconducting channels such as silicon, germanium and semiconductors with low-band-gap and large spin-orbit coupling.

Intellectual Merit: In order to design and fabricate high-performance semiconductor spintronic devices, a novel technique to tune the interface resistance of the ferromagnet/semiconductor tunnel contacts using a thin layer of non-magnetic, low-work-function layer is explored. This approach allows exploration of suitable low-work-function materials for manipulating interface properties and novel device designs to achieve efficient semiconductor-based spin electronics.

Broader Impacts: This research will establish a new direction with significant impact on the field of spin electronics and thus make possible new generations of novel devices with multi-functionalities. The advantages of spin-based devices include low power consumption, high storage density and transistors with low leakage currents and switching energies. The integrated educational and outreach component of this research will provide novel content for new courses in nanotechnology, hands-on learning opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students as well as District of Columbia high school students and teachers, especially for the large population of minority and under-represented students. This program also covers diverse aspects of science and engineering including semiconductor processing, device design and fabrication and ultra-high vacuum techniques that are essential for a technology-based economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the project were i) to synthesize and characterize novel ferromagnetic nanostructures for understanding spin-based carrier transport and ii) to understand the carrier spin transport through nanoscale semiconducting channels. In this project, we have shown that the carrier spins can be transported through nanoscale channels of tellurium, a low bandgap semiconductor. Tellurium is an interesting material that display semiconducting behavior, large spin-orbit coupling, and anisotropic electrical conductivity. We have fabricated nanoscale devices with tellurium nanowires and it was found that carrier spins can be transported through tellurium to long distances. The spin travels through tellurium nanowires without flipping its direction to a distance of around 350 nm at 10 K.  In a similar fashion, we have studied whether, through indium oxide, a transparent semiconductor, carrier spins can be transported in a nanoscale device structure. The indium oxide channels with dimensions 2000 x 75 nm were deposited using electron beam evaporation. We have observed that in indium oxide electron spin can travel to larger distances, almost ~1000 nm without flipping its direction at 5 K. In addition, we have grown CoTe magnetic nanostructures that display both ferrimagnetic and semiconducting behaviors beyond room temperature.  We have studied another interesting system at the nanoscale, it is a Heusler alloy, cobalt-iron-aluminum. Nanowires were grown and studied their structural, magnetic and electrical transport properties. We have observed that cobalt-iron-aluminum nanowires are ferromagnetic beyond 1000 K and display metallic behavior. Also, we have shown the experimental realization of two core-shell nanostructures FeCo/CoFe2O4 and FeNi/NixFe3-xO4 systems, the FeNi/NixFe3-xO4 system show exchange bias effect.

 

Two graduate students have worked on this project. The first student received prestigious NRC postdoctoral fellowship and is currently working as a scientist and the second student is currently doing a postdoctoral fellowship in the US. We have organized four nanotechnology workshops for high school students in the DC metro area. Most of the students who participated in these workshops are currently doing higher studies in STEM-related fields. We have also organized two nanotechnology workshops for high school teachers from local DC metro area.
